title: 106_hr4500
content: The Act may be cited as the "National Science Foundation Authorization Act of 2000" and authorizes appropriations. In fiscal year 2001, $3,773,710,000 is authorized to the National Science Foundation. Specific allocations include $2,813,500,000 for Research and Related Activities, with amounts designated for Biological Sciences, Computer and Information Science, Engineering, and Geosciences. In fiscal year 2001, the National Science Foundation is authorized $3,773,710,000. Specific allocations include $2,813,500,000 for Research and Related Activities, with amounts designated for various fields such as Biological Sciences, Computer and Information Science, Engineering, Geosciences, Mathematical and Physical Sciences, Social, Behavioral, and Economic Sciences, United States Polar Research Programs, United States Antarctic Logistical Support Activities, Integrative Activities, and Education and Human Resources including Graduate Research Fellowships. In fiscal year 2001, the National Science Foundation is authorized $3,773,710,000 for various fields including Research and Related Activities, Biological Sciences, Computer Science, Engineering, Geosciences, Mathematical Sciences, Social Sciences, United States Polar Research Programs, Antarctic Support Activities, Integrative Activities, and Education and Human Resources. $65,340,000 is allocated for Graduate Research Fellowships, $160,580,000 for Salaries and Expenses, and $17,440,000 for EarthScope, $16,400,000 for Large Hadron Collider, $6,000,000 for Millimeter Array, $12,000,000 for National Ecological Observatory Network, and $13,500,000 for South Pole Station under Major Research Equipment. In fiscal year 2002, the National Science Foundation is authorized $3,926,164,000. $2,909,490,000 is allocated for Research and Related Activities, including $496,955,000 for Biological Sciences and $10,103,000 for Computer and Information Science and Engineering. Salaries and Expenses total $160,580,000, with $4,700,000 for travel and $6,280,000 for the Office of Inspector General. In fiscal year 2002, the National Science Foundation is authorized $3,926,164,000. Funding allocations include $417,422,000 for Engineering, $568,486,000 for Geosciences, $834,740,000 for Mathematical and Physical Sciences, $165,242,000 for Social, Behavioral, and Economic Sciences, $228,508,000 for United States Polar Research Programs, $64,736,000 for United States Antarctic Logistical Support Activities, and $123,298,000 for Integrative Activities. In fiscal year 2002, the National Science Foundation is authorized $3,926,164,000. Funding allocations include $751,866,000 for Education and Human Resources, $90,900,000 for Major Research Equipment, and $167,094,000 for Salaries and Expenses. In fiscal year 2002, the National Science Foundation is authorized $3,926,164,000. $6,494,000 shall be made available for the Office of Inspector General. Funds shall not be used to employ more than 75 full-time equivalent positions in the Office of the Director for fiscal year 2001 or 2002. SEC. 3. PLANT GENOMICS. The National Science Foundation can provide grants for regional plant genome and gene expression research centers to develop basic plant genome research, extend genomics research through breeding programs, and serve as scientific information hubs. Grant awards will be given through a competitive process to ensure representation of various agronomic environments. The National Science Foundation will not provide more than 50% of the cost for establishing any research and development center. They may use up to $3,000,000 for fiscal year 2001 and $3,100,000 for fiscal year 2002 to carry out this section. SEC. 4. RESEARCH ON LEARNING. The National Science Foundation will provide grant awards for research on learning in four key areas: brain research, behavioral and cognitive aspects of learning, STEM learning in formal and informal settings, and learning in complex educational systems. The research aims to integrate scientific disciplines, understand the connection between research and education, and test hypotheses across disciplines. The National Science Foundation will provide grants for the establishment of research centers on learning to support multidisciplinary teams of researchers. $25,000,000 for fiscal year 2001 and $29,000,000 for fiscal year 2002 will be available for this purpose. Additionally, $6,000,000 for fiscal year 2001 is allocated for the establishment of these centers through a peer-reviewed competition. The National Science Foundation will sponsor a conference on human learning and education research within 6 months of the enactment of this Act. $25,000,000 for fiscal year 2001 and $28,000,000 for fiscal year 2002 will be available for the Interagency Education Research Initiative. The National Science Foundation will sponsor a conference on human learning and education research to review past research, assess current efforts, and develop recommendations for outstanding research issues across various disciplines. SEC. 5. TECHNICAL AMENDMENTS. The National Science Foundation Act of 1950 is amended to make technical changes. SEC. 6. REPORTS ELIMINATION. Section 3003(a)(1) of the Federal Reports Elimination and Sunset Act of 1995 does not apply to reports required under specific provisions of various laws related to science and engineering, including the National Science Foundation Act of 1950 and the High-Performance Computing Act of 1991. Section 7(a) of the National Science Foundation Authorization Act, 1977 (42 U.S.C. 1873 note) is referenced.
